questions.text: Which of the following cardioselective beta-blockers has been shown to decrease mortality in patients with congestive heart failure? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bisoprolol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bisoprolol is a cardioselective beta-blocker that has been shown to decrease mortality in patients with chronic congestive heart failure.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drug is associated with increased risk of urinary tract infections? ( INICET May 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dapagliflozin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In summary, dapagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, is associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections due to its mechanism of increasing glucose excretion in the urine. This patient’s recurrent UTIs could be related to her use of dapagliflozin.

questions.text: A victim of road traffic accident (RTA) presents with fracture of hand with hypothenar atrophy. Nerve involved in him is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ulnar nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypothenar atrophy is a clinical sign of ulnar nerve injury.
  • ➤ Hypothenar atrophy is a clinical sign of ulnar nerve injury.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents with the following x-ray of knee. It is suggestive of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Osteosarcoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Codman's triangle on an X-ray is a suggestive sign of osteosarcoma, a malignant bone tumor.
  • ➤ Codman's triangle on an X-ray is a suggestive sign of osteosarcoma, a malignant bone tumor.

questions.text: All of the following are associated with good prognosis in schizophrenia, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Late onset (Incorrect) : Advanced age of onset (>35 years) is associated with better prognosis in schizophrenia. Early onset (<20 years) is linked to poorer outcomes. Option B. Presence of Depression (Incorrect) : The presence of affective symptoms, including depression, is associated with better prognosis in schizophrenia. Option D. Acute onset (Incorrect) : Acute or abrupt onset of symptoms is associated with better prognosis compared to insidious onset.
  • • Option A. Late onset (Incorrect) : Advanced age of onset (>35 years) is associated with better prognosis in schizophrenia. Early onset (<20 years) is linked to poorer outcomes.
  • • Option A. Late onset (Incorrect)
  • • Option B. Presence of Depression (Incorrect) : The presence of affective symptoms, including depression, is associated with better prognosis in schizophrenia.
  • • Option B. Presence of Depression (Incorrect)
  • • Option D. Acute onset (Incorrect) : Acute or abrupt onset of symptoms is associated with better prognosis compared to insidious onset.
  • • Option D. Acute onset (Incorrect)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Good prognostic factors in schizophrenia include acute/abrupt onset, later age of onset (>35 years), female gender, presence of affective symptoms, and predominant positive symptoms. Poor prognostic factors include insidious onset, early onset (<20 years), male gender, predominant negative symptoms, and absence of affective symptoms.

questions.text: Which is the Nodal Ministry for Disaster Management? (FMGE JAN 2025)

options.label: A
options.text: Ministry of Health and Family Welfare

options.label: C
options.text: Ministry of Environment, Forests and Climate Change

options.label: D
options.text: Ministry of Social Justice and Empowerment

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ministry of Home Affairs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Ministry of Home Affairs serves as the nodal ministry for disaster management in India, with the district being the nodal center for implementation. NDMA functions under the Ministry of Home Affairs with the Prime Minister as its chairperson.

questions.text: What is the term for a primary skin lesion that is flat, without elevation or depression, and less than 1 cm in diameter? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Macule

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A macule is a flat, non-palpable, circumscribed lesion less than 1 cm in diameter that represents a change in skin color without alteration in skin texture or thickness.
  • ➤ A macule is a flat, non-palpable, circumscribed lesion less than 1 cm in diameter that represents a change in skin color without alteration in skin texture or thickness.
  • ➤ macule
  • ➤ flat, non-palpable, circumscribed lesion less than 1 cm
  • ➤ change in skin color

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is least likely to impair scholastic performance? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • PICA is an eating disorder characterized by the persistent consumption of non-nutritive, non-food substances (such as dirt, clay, paper, paint chips, etc.) that is inappropriate for the developmental level of the individual. While PICA can have health consequences due to ingestion of potentially harmful substances, it does not directly impact cognitive functions or learning abilities in the way the other listed conditions do. Therefore, PICA is least likely to directly impair scholastic performance.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) (Incorrect) : ADHD is characterized by inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity. These symptoms directly interfere with learning processes, classroom behavior, and academic achievement. Children with ADHD often struggle with focusing during lessons, completing assignments, following instructions, and staying organized, all of which significantly impact scholastic performance. Option B. Specific Learning Disability (SLD) (Incorrect) : SLD is defined by significant impairment in one or more specific academic skills (reading, writing, mathematics) despite normal intellectual functioning. By definition, SLD directly impacts scholastic performance, as it specifically affects the acquisition and use of academic skills. Option C. Anxiety (Incorrect) : Anxiety disorders can significantly impair scholastic performance through several mechanisms. Test anxiety can lead to underperformance in examinations, social anxiety can interfere with class participation and group activities, and generalized anxiety can affect concentration, working memory, and overall cognitive functioning in the classroom setting.
  • • Option A. Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) (Incorrect) : ADHD is characterized by inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity. These symptoms directly interfere with learning processes, classroom behavior, and academic achievement. Children with ADHD often struggle with focusing during lessons, completing assignments, following instructions, and staying organized, all of which significantly impact scholastic performance.
  • • Option A. Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) (Incorrect)
  • • Option B. Specific Learning Disability (SLD) (Incorrect) : SLD is defined by significant impairment in one or more specific academic skills (reading, writing, mathematics) despite normal intellectual functioning. By definition, SLD directly impacts scholastic performance, as it specifically affects the acquisition and use of academic skills.
  • • Option B. Specific Learning Disability (SLD) (Incorrect)
  • • Option C. Anxiety (Incorrect) : Anxiety disorders can significantly impair scholastic performance through several mechanisms. Test anxiety can lead to underperformance in examinations, social anxiety can interfere with class participation and group activities, and generalized anxiety can affect concentration, working memory, and overall cognitive functioning in the classroom setting.
  • • Option C. Anxiety (Incorrect)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When considering psychiatric disorders that impact academic performance, it's important to differentiate between conditions that directly affect cognitive functions, learning processes, or classroom behavior (like ADHD, learning disabilities, and anxiety) versus conditions that primarily affect other domains of functioning (like certain eating disorders). PICA, as an eating disorder characterized by consumption of non-food substances, has physiological and health implications but does not directly impact the cognitive processes essential for learning.

questions.text: All of the following are true about dementia and differentiate it from delirium, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Clouding of consciousness is a characteristic feature of delirium, not dementia. The disturbance of consciousness is considered one of the hallmark symptoms of delirium and represents a key distinguishing feature between these two neurocognitive disorders.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Insidious onset (Incorrect) : Dementia typically has an insidious onset with gradual progression, while delirium has a sudden onset. This is a true differentiating feature of dementia. Option B. Often irreversible (Incorrect) : Most dementias are irreversible and progressive conditions, unlike delirium which is usually reversible if the underlying cause is identified and treated. This is a true differentiating feature of dementia. Option D. Impaired remote memory (Incorrect) : In dementia, memory impairment follows a pattern where recent memory is affected first, followed by immediate memory, and finally remote memory in later stages. In delirium, immediate and recent memory are primarily affected while remote memory remains relatively intact. Impaired remote memory in later stages is a feature of dementia.
  • • Option A. Insidious onset (Incorrect) : Dementia typically has an insidious onset with gradual progression, while delirium has a sudden onset. This is a true differentiating feature of dementia.
  • • Option A. Insidious onset (Incorrect)
  • • Option B. Often irreversible (Incorrect) : Most dementias are irreversible and progressive conditions, unlike delirium which is usually reversible if the underlying cause is identified and treated. This is a true differentiating feature of dementia.
  • • Option B. Often irreversible (Incorrect)
  • • Option D. Impaired remote memory (Incorrect) : In dementia, memory impairment follows a pattern where recent memory is affected first, followed by immediate memory, and finally remote memory in later stages. In delirium, immediate and recent memory are primarily affected while remote memory remains relatively intact. Impaired remote memory in later stages is a feature of dementia.
  • • Option D. Impaired remote memory (Incorrect)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key differences between dementia and delirium include: dementia has insidious onset and progressive course while delirium has sudden onset and fluctuating course; consciousness is preserved in dementia but disturbed in delirium; and dementia is often irreversible whereas delirium is usually reversible when the underlying cause is treated.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a focal non-cicatricial cause of alopecia? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Discoid Lupus Erythematosus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Discoid Lupus Erythematosus (DLE) is a cause of focal cicatricial alopecia and thus is not classified among focal non-cicatricial causes of hair loss.
  • ➤ Discoid Lupus Erythematosus (DLE) is a cause of focal cicatricial alopecia and thus is not classified among focal non-cicatricial causes of hair loss.
  • ➤ Discoid Lupus Erythematosus (DLE)
  • ➤ focal cicatricial alopecia

questions.text: Which of the following is not a classical histological feature of Lichen Planus? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Munro microabscess.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Munro microabscesses are a classical histological feature of psoriasis , not lichen planus, which is characterized by Max Joseph clefts, Civatte bodies, and sawtooth rete ridges.
  • ➤ Munro microabscesses are a classical histological feature of psoriasis , not lichen planus, which is characterized by Max Joseph clefts, Civatte bodies, and sawtooth rete ridges.
  • ➤ Munro microabscesses
  • ➤ psoriasis
  • ➤ lichen planus,
  • ➤ Max Joseph clefts, Civatte bodies, and sawtooth rete ridges.

questions.text: A bronchial asthma patient who is on inhalational steroids presented with white patchy lesions on the tongue and buccal mucosa. What is the drug that can be used to treat this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Clotrimazole

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clotrimazole is the drug of choice for treating oral candidiasis, especially in patients who develop the condition as a side effect of inhalational steroid use. It works by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis, compromising the fungal cell membrane integrity.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not likely to cause a pleural pathology? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Metformin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Metformin is not associated with causing pleural pathologies, unlike Methysergide, Bleomycin, and Nitrofurantoin, which have known risks of causing pleural and pulmonary complications.

questions.text: Theophylline was prescribed to a male patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The next day, he noticed that his urine output had increased. Which of the following receptors is responsible for the drug's action? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Adenosine A1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Theophylline increases urine output by antagonizing adenosine A1 receptors, leading to decreased water reabsorption in the renal tubules and resulting in diuresis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old chronic hypertensive woman visits the outpatient department for pre-conceptional counseling. Which of the following anti-hypertensive should she discontinue? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ACE inhibitors should be discontinued in women who are planning to conceive due to their associated risks of fetal renal dysplasia, oligohydramnios, and other congenital anomalies. Alternative antihypertensive medications that are safer during pregnancy include labetalol, calcium channel blockers, and alpha methyldopa.

questions.text: Delusions are commonly observed in all of the following conditions, except: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Conversion Disorder (also called Functional Neurological Symptom Disorder or Dissociative Neurological Symptom Disorder in ICD-11) is characterized by neurological symptoms like paralysis, blindness, or seizures that cannot be explained by medical conditions. Importantly, delusions are not a feature of conversion disorder. Conversion disorder involves a psychological stressor that manifests as physical symptoms, but the patient does not have false, fixed beliefs (delusions) about their condition.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Schizophrenia (Incorrect) : Delusions are core symptoms of schizophrenia. According to the DSM-5 criteria, delusions are one of the characteristic positive symptoms required for diagnosis. Option B. Depression (Incorrect) : Delusions can develop in a patient with depression. These may include delusions of guilt, nihilistic delusions (e.g., believing internal organs have rotted), or delusions of poverty. Option C. Dementia (Incorrect) : Delusions can occur in dementia, particularly in moderate to severe stages. These are usually transient and less complex than those seen in primary psychotic disorders. Common delusions in dementia include persecutory delusions, delusions of theft, or misidentification delusions.
  • • Option A. Schizophrenia (Incorrect) : Delusions are core symptoms of schizophrenia. According to the DSM-5 criteria, delusions are one of the characteristic positive symptoms required for diagnosis.
  • • Option A. Schizophrenia (Incorrect)
  • • Option B. Depression (Incorrect) : Delusions can develop in a patient with depression. These may include delusions of guilt, nihilistic delusions (e.g., believing internal organs have rotted), or delusions of poverty.
  • • Option B. Depression (Incorrect)
  • • Option C. Dementia (Incorrect) : Delusions can occur in dementia, particularly in moderate to severe stages. These are usually transient and less complex than those seen in primary psychotic disorders. Common delusions in dementia include persecutory delusions, delusions of theft, or misidentification delusions.
  • • Option C. Dementia (Incorrect)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Delusions are common features of psychotic disorders like schizophrenia, severe mood disorders with psychotic features (including depression), and neurocognitive disorders like dementia. Conversion disorder, however, is characterized by unexplained neurological symptoms without the presence of delusions, as it belongs to the somatic symptom/dissociative disorder category rather than the psychotic spectrum.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a history of bronchial asthma in third stage of labor. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in the management of postpartum hemorrhage in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Carboprost

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Carboprost should be avoided in the management of postpartum hemorrhage in patients with a history of bronchial asthma due to its potential to cause bronchoconstriction.

questions.text: A patient with deep vein thrombosis was started on a new drug. After 2 days, he presented with the given finding. Which of the following drugs is implicated in causing the below condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Warfarin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Warfarin can cause dermal vascular necrosis, particularly in patients with protein C deficiency, presenting as painful, necrotic skin lesions shortly after initiation of therapy.

questions.text: A two-year-old boy presents with delayed speech, difficulties in communication, and repetitive behaviors such as staring at his own hands. He struggles with making friends and concentrating. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical presentation strongly suggests Autism (now classified as Autism Spectrum Disorder in current diagnostic systems). The key features presented in this case include:
  • • Delayed speech and difficulties in communication (language impairment) Repetitive behaviors (staring at hands) which represent restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior Social interaction difficulties (struggles with making friends) Age of presentation before 3 years (the child is 2 years old)
  • • Delayed speech and difficulties in communication (language impairment)
  • • Repetitive behaviors (staring at hands) which represent restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior
  • • Social interaction difficulties (struggles with making friends)
  • • Age of presentation before 3 years (the child is 2 years old)
  • • These symptoms align perfectly with the core diagnostic criteria of autism, which includes impairments in social interaction, and restricted/repetitive behaviors. Communication deficits are also often seen in autism.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. ADHD (Incorrect) : While ADHD can present with concentration difficulties, it typically doesn't include speech delays, repetitive behaviors, or social interaction difficulties as primary symptoms. ADHD is characterized primarily by inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity. Option C. Mental Retardation (Incorrect) : Now termed Intellectual Disability, this condition involves below-average intellectual functioning and adaptive behavior. While intellectual disability can co-occur with autism (around 30% of cases), the repetitive behaviors and specific social interaction difficulties described are more characteristic of autism than isolated intellectual disability. Option D. Specific Learning Disability (Incorrect) : Learning disabilities involve difficulties in specific academic skills (reading, writing, mathematics) out of proportion to the intellectual functioning of the child. They aren't typically diagnosed in toddlers as these skills aren't yet expected, and they don't explain the communication deficits, repetitive behaviors, or social difficulties described.
  • • Option B. ADHD (Incorrect) : While ADHD can present with concentration difficulties, it typically doesn't include speech delays, repetitive behaviors, or social interaction difficulties as primary symptoms. ADHD is characterized primarily by inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity.
  • • Option B. ADHD (Incorrect)
  • • Option C. Mental Retardation (Incorrect) : Now termed Intellectual Disability, this condition involves below-average intellectual functioning and adaptive behavior. While intellectual disability can co-occur with autism (around 30% of cases), the repetitive behaviors and specific social interaction difficulties described are more characteristic of autism than isolated intellectual disability.
  • • Option C. Mental Retardation (Incorrect)
  • • Intellectual Disability,
  • • Option D. Specific Learning Disability (Incorrect) : Learning disabilities involve difficulties in specific academic skills (reading, writing, mathematics) out of proportion to the intellectual functioning of the child. They aren't typically diagnosed in toddlers as these skills aren't yet expected, and they don't explain the communication deficits, repetitive behaviors, or social difficulties described.
  • • Option D. Specific Learning Disability (Incorrect)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Autism is characterized by impairments in social interaction, and restricted/repetitive behaviors. Communication deficits are also often present in autism. These symptoms typically manifest before age 3, making early identification possible.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has experienced the loss of her newborn. She is currently producing breast milk, leading to discomfort and the risk of developing a breast abscess due to milk stasis and incomplete emptying. Which of the following drug can be used to prevent this complication? ( INICET May 2024)
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Cabergoline

questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient has been diagnosed with tuberculosis and is about to begin antitubercular therapy (ATT) that includes rifampicin. She is currently taking oral contraceptives (OCP) for birth control. The clinician advises her to use an additional barrier method of contraception while undergoing treatment. What is the primary reason for this recommendation? (NEET PG 2021)

options.label: C
options.text: Because rifampicin can decrease OCP metabolism

options.label: D
options.text: Because rifampicin can induce OCP metabolism and cause failure

questions.correct_answer: D. Because rifampicin can induce OCP metabolism and cause failure
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Rifampicin is known to induce hepatic enzymes that speed up the metabolism of various drugs, including oral contraceptives. This can lead to lower blood levels of the hormones in OCPs, thereby reducing their efficacy and increasing the risk of contraceptive failure. Hence, it is advised for patients on both medications to use an additional barrier method of contraception.

questions.text: A pregnant woman was prescribed indomethacin. Which of the following effects does the drug have on the fetus? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.correct_answer: A. Premature closure of ductus arteriosus
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Indomethacin, an NSAID, can cause the premature closure of the ductus arteriosus in a fetus due to its inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis. Therefore, caution should be exercised when prescribing this drug to pregnant women, particularly in the third trimester.

questions.text: Which of the following is a PCSK-9 inhibtior? ( INICET May 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Evolocumab

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In summary, evolocumab is the correct answer as it is a PCSK-9 inhibitor used to lower LDL cholesterol levels.

questions.text: A patient with mild to moderate renal failure requires reversal of muscle relaxation induced by vecuronium. Which of the following drugs is appropriate for this purpose? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sugammadex

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sugammadex is the appropriate agent for reversing the effects of vecuronium in patients with mild to moderate renal failure due to its specific action on non-depolarizing muscle relaxants and its faster onset of action.

questions.text: The image of the mascot ‘Sapna’ shown below and identify what does she represent in the national health program: (FMGE JAN 2025)

options.label: A
options.text: NLEP, leprosy has a vaccine available

options.label: C
options.text: NLEP, Leprosy is curable, reduce stigma, spread awareness

questions.correct_answer: C. NLEP, Leprosy is curable, reduce stigma, spread awareness
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) NLEP, Leprosy is curable, reduce stigma, spread awareness

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sapna is the mascot of NLEP who represents successful treatment of leprosy and aims to reduce stigma while spreading awareness about curability of the disease through multi-drug therapy.
